Executive Summary



1. The written corporate Health, Safety, and Environmental policy is: 



MISSION



To manufacture, market and distribute products in a responsible manner that protects the environment and safeguards the health, safety and security of employees, contractors, customers, and the community.



GUIDING PRINCIPLES



We will: 



?    Operate safe and secure workplaces and actively support each other in working safely.

?    Comply with applicable HSE laws and regulations of the countries in which we operate.

?    Act ethically, actively participate and take personal responsibility and accountability for HSE.

?    Integrate HSE management systems into our core business activities and planning processes.

?    Commit to pollution prevention by eliminating or reducing emissions, discharges, wastes and risks associated with our operations and products.

?    Continually improve by participating in voluntary initiatives like the Guiding Principles of Responsible Care®, RC14001, and ISO14001.

?    Communicate HSE performance and product information openly with employees, customers and the public.

?    Encourage responsible management throughout product life cycles, including safe use, transport and disposal.

?    Support sustainable development by using recycled materials, reducing energy consumption, offering environmentally-friendly products and respecting the well-being of our employees and the environment.

?    Review our HSE performance regularly and ensure that appropriate standards, practices, resources and training are maintained. 



The above policy is implemented at the plant level through programs described in detail later in this document and through the following corporate wide programs: 



?    Eco Services Requirements and Recommendations

?    Maintenance Integrity and Maintenance Management (MIMM) 

?    Process Hazardous Management Program (PHMP)



The Martinez Plant Health, Safety, Security, & Environmental Program provides a consolidated version of these progr

ams.  Audits are regularly conducted to ensure that these programs are in place and functioning well at the Martinez Plant. 



2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled



The Martinez Plant utilizes a regeneration process to manufacture various strengths and grades of sulfuric acid. Its acid is used in the gasoline manufacturing process at refineries, metals mining, processing pulp and paper, agricultural chemicals and pesticides, and water treatment. The only chemical stored and used in the Martinez Plant that is covered by the EPA RMP regulation is anhydrous ammonia (NH3). The Plant uses anhydrous ammonia at its abatement tower to control sulfur dioxide emissions. This process generates ammonium bisulfite as a by-product fertilizer that is sold seasonally. 



3. Offsite Consequence Analysis



To evaluate the worst-case and alternate release scenarios for this RMP update and re-submittal, Martinez Plant used the EPA's RMP*Comp software program, and MARPLOT software for estimating population and for mapping.



Worst-Case Scenario



The Worst-Case Scenario (WCS) for ammonia stored on site is the release of the total contents of the storage tank of anhydrous ammonia (NH3) over a 10-minute period. No credit for mitigation measures was taken into account for this scenario.  



Alternate Release Scenario



An Alternate Release Scenario (ARS) for ammonia stored on site was selected from the results of the process hazard assessments that were completed for the ammonia storage unit. The ARS associated with the release of ammonia at the Martinez Plant is a leak in the hose during the unloading of an ammonia tank truck.



4. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The Martinez Plant has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth under 40 CFR part 68 for this covered process.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the

release prevention program that is in place at our facility.



Process Safety Information

The Martinez Plant maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment designs associated with all processes.



Process Hazard Analysis

Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodologies used for these analyses are What-Ifs and HazOps using LOPA and What-If Checklists.  The studies are performed by a cross-functional team of qualified personnel with expertise in risk analysis, engineering, process operations, and maintenance.  All process hazard analyses are revalidated every 5 years.  Any findings resulted from the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.



Operating Procedures

For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our processes, the Martinez Plant maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup after a turnaround. The information is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.  All operating procedures are reviewed and recertified annually.



Training

The Martinez Plant has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure all operations personnel are competent in the operating procedures associated with the processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every 3 years and more frequently as needed.



Mechanical Integrity

The Martinez Plant carries out documented maintenance inspections on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these inspections include among others; pressure vessels, storage tanks, pumps, piping systems, pressure relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, and controls.  Maintenance procedures are pe

rformed by qualified personnel with training in maintenance practices and the potential hazards associated with each unit.  Furthermore, specialized training is offered as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by these inspections are corrected in a safe and timely manner.  All corrective actions are tracked via a computerized work order management system.



Management of Change

Written procedures are in place at the Martinez Plant to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures.  All changes are reviewed for potential health, safety, or environmental concerns.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of the change and training is provided on the modification.  All relevant documentation and drawings are updated as part of the action items resulting from the changes.



Pre-startup Safety Reviews

Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at the Martinez Plant.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operation and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.  Pre-startup safety reviews are also performed for any process that has been idle for longer than six months.



Compliance Audits

The Martinez Plant conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented.  These audits are carried out at least every 3 years.  The plant's personnel are responsible for developing an action plan to address all recommendations resulting from audits in a timely manner.



Incident Investigation

The Martinez Plant promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in the release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situ

ation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent recurrences.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.



Employee Participation

The Martinez Plant believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, our employees have access to all information related to the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulted from process hazard analyses.



Apart from their participations in process hazard analyses, pre-startup safety reviews, and management of change reviews, employees are encouraged to participate on various health, safety, and environmental improvement teams that are active on site.



Contractors

Occasionally, our company hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  It is the Martinez Plant's policy to inform the contractors of the processes and known potential hazards related to the contractor's work.  Contractors are also informed of all the emergency response procedures should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.  Contractors working onsite are expected to work according to all of the safe work practice policies in place for our employees. 



5. Five-year Accident History



The Martinez Plant has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.  Due to our stringent release prevention policies, there have been no accidental releases during this period that meet the EPA definition of an RMP-reportable release.



6. Emergency Response Plan



The Martinez Plant maintains a well trained emergency response team and a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all

aspects of emergency response including first aid, medical treatment, evacuations, notifications of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.



To ensure proper functioning, the Plant's emergency response plan/system is tested by conducting drills and our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response. 



7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The Martinez Plant has developed a strong safety culture and embraces the continuous improvement of its safety program. Although no major changes are currently planned, the Martinez Plant implemented the following noteworthy changes that have improved safety and significantly reduced the overall risk footprint since the 2004 RMP re-submittal: 



1. In November 2004, the Plant completely ceased the production of oleum, de-inventoried, sanitized and isolated the oleum production unit.

2. In August 2006, the Plant implemented a significant reduction in its maximum onsite inventory of anhydrous ammonia through administrative control.
